title: Are advanced technologies going to kill all of us? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you’re talking about stupid wireless stuff,,, then it won’t immediately kill all of us, all at once… Like all carcinogens It’ll take 10–20 years for the effects to show.. Clinical studies have shown that wireless technology alters the functions of cell membranes… the voltage gated calcium channels in the cell membranes… Electromagnetic fields act via activation of voltage-gated http://calciumwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov (http://calciumwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) › pmc › articles › PMC3780531 Jun 26, 2013 — I probably could find a few thousand of these articles. We’ve known this wireless stuff is harmful since 1940… Even the World Health Organization says so and has classified it as a 2b carcinogen.. And the European Union is considering or has put a 2 year moratorium on 5 G wireless for fear of the effects on the health of their population. EU 5G Appeal - Scientists warn of potential serious health effects of 5G (EU 5G Appeal - Scientists warn of potential serious health effects of 5G) It also alters the use of insulin.. elevating blood sugar **Insulin** Receptors (IRs) embedded in their **cell membranes**. It causes elevated reactive oxygen species… from Nature, November 7, 2019…**Microwaves from mobile phone induce reactive oxygen species but not DNA damage, preleukemic fusion genes and apoptosis in hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells … ** * ** Published: 12 October 2015** (Polarization: A Key Difference between Man-made and Natural Electromagnetic Fields, in regard to Biological Activity Nature** **Polarization: A Key Difference between Man-made and Natural Electromagnetic Fields, in regard to Biological Activity** And then there are all the other pollutants. Our cell biology is harmed by heavy metals and fracking chemicals and herbicide and pesticide and fluoride compounds…, These pollutants absolutely do cause sickness and deaths… but usually no immediately. World wide, “” Pollution kills 9 million a year - three times more deaths than from AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria combined and 15 times more than from all wars and other forms of violence.” THE LANCET COMMISSIONS| VOLUME 391, ISSUE 10119, P 462-512, FEBRUARY 03, 201

I think the average person is far more likely to have his life prolonged by advanced technologies. During my lifetime, technology has given us many lifesaving devices, everything from artificial hearts to collision avoidance systems, with more being added all of the time. And anyway, as long as any one single person out of the billions on this planet dies of natural causes, then your answer is no, they won't kill “all" of us.
Nope, death will come to everyone by simple biology, as it has since life itself first began.
